title: Wednesday, 24th August, 2016

BE

EBITDA of $4.0bn came in
2% ahead of consensus with strong performance from Metals in industrial
and marketing offsetting weakness in energy and Ag. Net debt of $23.6bn
came in $700m below consensus at $23.6bn driven by a further ~$1.6bn
working capital reduction (we assumed a small build). Cash flow before
working capital movements and capex (FFO) of $2.8bn was ~$500m weaker
than our forecast of $3.3bn with higher interest costs (~$200m) partly to
blame. The disposal target of $4-5bn remains unchanged with $3.9bn
announced including today's announced sale of part of Ernest Henry. Unit
cost guidance has been lowered across the industrial business 2016.

11:14 am
BE

The company has hedged 55 mt of thermal coal production over the
next 12 months substantially reducing its exposure to current spot
prices: The company recognized MTM losses as of 30 June of $395m in
relation to derivative positions that were entered into in Q216 and manage
forward sales price exposure for 55 mt of thermal coal that will be sold in
H216 and H117. The MTM loss implies the contracts were $7/t out of the
money at 30 June and since the period end thermal prices have climbed from
~$58-59/t to $68-69/t implying further MTM losses in H216.

BE

Net debt: year-end net debt and net funding targets have been lowered to
$16.5-17.5bn and $31-32bn from $17-18bn and $32-33bn, although this
reduction reflects the proportional consolidation of the Ag business ($1.7bn
reduction). Without this, year-end net debt guidance has been increased by
$0.5-1.0bn with the company guiding to a $1bn working capital build in H216.

This is in line with our estimates but excludes the 55 mt coal hedge.

EBITDA beat butnet debt was above our forecasts due to one-off charges and
Fx movements. However, the company is well on track to meet its net debt
objective for 2016 of US$16.5-17.5bn with improved free cash generation on spot
commodity prices and disposal proceeds of US$4-5bn. The shares have
anticipated this and now trade above our base case PT although have an
attractive FCFyield of 12% om spot as capex remains depressed and prices have
recovered slightly. Maintain EW.

BE

WPP net sales and headline operating profit ahead of our/Zone Finance expectations, with adj. diluted EPS
+3.7%/2.9% ahead of JPMe/BBG consensus. Q2 org sales growth of 4.3% was 100bps ahead of JPMe/Zone
Finance consensus of 3.3%/3.3% respectively. The outlook for the remainder of 2016 is slightly altered,
maintaining the net sales growth forecast of over 3% but highlighting a slightly weaker H2 than H1, which we
believe is just tempering expectations following a strong beat in Q2. Revenues are now expected to grow ‘well
over’ 3%. July organic net sales growth of 1.9%, which WPP states is ahead of budget given the strong
comparator of +3.7% in July 2015.

11:27 am
PM

(Spoiler: certain advertisers are now diverting money into directly paying journalists.)

BE

( omg smile )

BE

H116 Net Sales and Op. Profit ahead of JPMe. WPP H116 net sales of £5,594m (+11% y/y) were +1.4% vs
JPMe of £5,515mn and +1.1% vs consensus (source: Zone Finance) of £5,534mn. H116 organic net sales
growth of +3.8% y/y, was +50bps ahead of JPMe of +3.3% and +60bps ahead of consensus. On a quarterly
basis Q216 net sales increased +4.3% y/y organically which was 100bps ahead of JPMe/consensus (see Table
2 for more detail). H116 Headline operating profit of £769m (+14.9% y/y) was +2.5% vs JPMe of £750mn
and +1.9% vs consensus of £755mn, implying a net sales margin of 13.7% (+40bps y/y), +10bps vs JPMe
/consensus. At constant currency margin increased by 30bps. H116 Diluted Headline EPS grew +17% y/y to
39.1p, +3.7% ahead of JPMe of 37.7p. WPP did have an exceptional write-down of £122mn in the half,
primarily reflecting its investment in ComScore. The buyback has progressed a bit slower than we had
expected, with the equivalent of a 1% reduction in share count vs a 2% reduction in H1 2015. WPP declared a
H116 interim dividend of 19.55p per share, up +23% y/y.
 Outlook: The outlook for the remainder of 2016 is slightly altered, maintaining the net sales growth forecast
of over 3% but highlighting a slightly weaker H2 than H1. We believe this is just tempering expectations
following a very strong Q2 net sales growth. Revenues are now expected to grow ‘well over’ 3% vs just over
3% previously. The long term guidance is unchanged.
 Regions: North America was strong with net sales org growth of +4.0% in Q2 (Q1 +3.9%), bucking the trend
printed by peers of weaker than expected organic growth in the region. The strength was from Advertising and
Media Investment Management. UK net sales org growth of 3.4% y/y was 20bps higher than our expectation
but 90bpps ahead of consensus in Q2 (Q1: +3.2%). For July WPP states the UK was stronger than the
previous quarter, perhaps reflecting a post-Brexit vote recovery, driven by a weaker pound sterling. For
Western Continental Europe overall org net sales increased from 2.3% in Q1 to +6.2% in Q2. Asia Pacific,
Latin America, Africa & the Middle East and Central & Eastern Europe grew 3.8% compared to 3.0% in Q1.
India’s net sales grew +17% organically whilst China remained ‘sluggish’.

11:28 am
BE

Sorry about the formatting. I'm sure the people complaining about the typesetting of the organogram will be apoplectic about that.

BE

Goldman too, just for variety.

BE

What's changed
WPP reported a strong set of 1H results with net sales and margins both
ahead of expectations. Key takeaways: 1) Organic growth accelerated to
4.3% in 2Q, above GS/ZoneFinance consensus of 3.2%, from 3.2% in 1Q,
mainly driven by Cont EU. The UK and US were also stronger than
expected, but RoW was softer (Greater China sluggish). The US growth
was particularly reassuring given most other agencies had missed in 2Q.
2) Margins were up 40bp including a 10bp boost from FX vs. GS/cons
30bp. We already have 40bp FY incl. 10bp from FX, while consensus is still
at 30bp. 3) Reassurance on market research turnaround with the segment
posting 2.0% growth in 2Q after -0.1% in 1Q, and margins up 180bp yoy
reflecting the benefit of recent restructuring. The fact that Kantar’s growth
is coming at a lower cost partly explains the reversal of the gap in revenue
vs. net sales growth in 2Q. 4) July was indicated up 1.9%, which we
believe reflects some phasing of spend into 2Q and tough comps (+3.7%).
WPP also expects a slower 2H due to tougher comps but reiterated FY
outlook of over 3% (consensus is 3.1% implying only +2.5% in 2H). Buy.
Implications
We raise our 2016/17E organic growth to 3.4%/3.0% from 3.1%/2.8% and
our 2017E margin by 10 bp to 17.6%, partly offset by higher interest costs
and share count. Our EPS increases slightly to 111.6p/127.3p in 2016/17E
(consensus 107.2p/117.0p).
Valuation
At 13.7x 2017E P/E, we believe valuation is attractive given a c.3% organic
net sales and c.11% EPS CAGR 2016-19E, with 3.8% dividend yield, hence
we remain Buy. Our 12m price target increases by 4.5% to 1970p (1886p)
and is based on 15.5x 2017E P/E (from 15.0x) to reflect the better outlook.
Key risks
Macro slowdown, account losses and value-destructive M&A

11:30 am
BE

It was quite fun yesterday. Our comment count would've been in the low teens without DPL.

PM

I will share this Reuters column

PM

Britain’s housing crisis is hiding in plain sight. UK average house prices are over five time average earnings, according to Halifax data, and despite the shock of Brexit housing transactions were largely unaffected in July, according to official data released on Aug. 23. Persimmon’s 36 percent return on capital employed, revealed with the UK builder’s first-half results on the same day, is a sign that this is a malfunctioning market.

In theory, an environment in which companies make returns of this scale when they only need around 9 percent to meet their weighted average cost of capital – and thus investor expectations – should attract new entrants. One reason this doesn’t happen is smaller rivals went bust in the aftermath of the 2008 crisis, and can’t get access to finance from wary banks now. A bigger issue is Britain’s sclerotic planning system – politically motivated opposition to development makes it hard for developers to know whether consent will take months or years.

Builders typically deal with the uncertainty by factoring in a gross profit margin of around 20 percent when they sell a house. If land and construction costs make this unfeasible, they can attempt to maintain their selling price by controlling the supply of new houses they sell every year. Persimmon has 93,519 so-called consented plots of land, and said at its full-year results it has over six years’ supply on which to build its houses.

High returns today have to be weighed against poor returns in the past. Persimmon’s nine-year average return on capital is just under 15 percent, factoring in low returns following the 2008 crash. Rival Barratt Developments, which made a 24 percent return on capital employed in 2015, shows a similar trend. But the UK’s current figure of around 150,000 new houses a year is 100,000 off what’s needed. If builders didn’t need to make their 20 percent margins, they could get away with selling houses for lower prices than the 205,762 pounds average recorded by Persimmon in the first half.

11:31 am
PM

That makes housebuilders’ profitability a political issue. Prime Minister Theresa May asserted on July 11 that Britain has a “housing deficit” between rich homeowners and stymied renters. That may not seem too different to what her predecessor David Cameron said. But May has also railed against policy being set for big business.

The new government may not be able to do much about the basic political problems caused by slow planning, which itself reflects that the majority of Britons own their own home and don’t want prices to fall. But if it senses that large builders’ returns are getting too high, there are levers to pull. It could capitalise a public sector bank to lend to smaller builders who can’t compete effectively, or it could build the houses publicly – like it used to do in the 1960s and 1970s, when 300,000 houses were routinely built annually. Both might make house prices fall.

May could also scrap the previous government’s Help to Buy scheme, in which the government guarantees the riskiest bits of high loan-to-value mortgages for first-time buyers. That helps keep prices high, and forces taxpayers to take the risk for the benefit of the few. It also gives builders an unnecessary leg-up – over 40 percent of Persimmon’s new volumes stem from those assisted by Help to Buy.

Housebuilders didn’t make the UK housing market as dysfunctional as it is. But having nearly collapsed in 2008, they now look strong enough to deal with a tougher operating environment. Persimmon has net cash. And, like peers, it also has an inbuilt defence mechanism against low prices – it can just stop buying new land and generate cash by running down what it has.

None of this would be very good for shareholders in the largest building groups. But builders privately admit that a market in which house prices grow steadily in line with inflation would suit them much better than one that comes with booms and busts. The need to make both the UK housing market and builder returns less excessive are two sides of the same coin.

PM

The Group has developed its own team-based ‘Pods’ organisational structure for its new business acquisition
activities. The Directors believe that this Pods structure is an important driver of the Group’s efficient growth
metrics and that the associated recruiting methodology, focus on process and team-based incentivisation
scheme form a highly scalable and repeatable template for future growth. In FY2015, a typical Pod delivered
annual recurring LoopUp Revenue growth of approximately £440,0008. The Directors also note that the
Group’s historic growth has been accomplished with little-to-no investment in inbound marketing.

BE

11:43 am
BE

There are currently six Pods, two in London, two in San Francisco, one in New York and one in Boston. A typical Pod comprises a mix of business development (three), sales (two) and account management (one) members. Bonus payments are made solely on each Pod’s – rather than individual – performance, solely based on recurring revenue growth.

Business development Pod members are incentivised only to seek qualified opportunities with genuine target market revenue potential. Similarly, sales Pod members are incentivised only to close accounts with genuine target market revenue potential.

All but two of the Group’s 37 Pod members18 were hired via new graduate recruitment channels and, as such, the supply of future recruits for further Pod scaling is both plentiful and cost effective. All six Pods work to highly consistent, proven and efficient methods and processes, tightly integrated into the Group’s CRM platform.

PM

It is true that OneSavings has already rebounded by 35% over the past 8 weeks but, in our view, that is grossly inadequate relative to the (we think) stunning performance demonstrated in today’s H1 2016 results. Reported profit before tax is up 115% YoY to £100m. The CET1 ratio is up by 2.3% YoY to 13.3%. U/L PBT (OSB definition) of £64.6m is 1% better than us and 7% ahead of company-compiled consensus (£60.3m). Moreover, we think that OSB’s outlook remains much more robust than the market expects. BUY.

PM

The interim dividend is raised by 45% to 2.9p. We forecast 10.0p for full-year 2016e giving a prospective 2016e dividend yield of 4.2%. Within our banks coverage, only Lloyds (Buy) and HSBC (Sell) offer more. However, the valuation disparity is, we think, absurd. Despite its recent “bounce”, OSB trades on 5x 2016e EPS vs Lloyds and HSBC on 12x and 18x respectively!

We believe that it is little surprise to see OSB post a sharp 25% increase in organic origination to £973m (vs a record £778m in H1 2015). Moreover the run-rate of applications in H2 2016 has (so far) increased vs H1 2016!

U/L PBT (OSB’s definition) of £64.6m is a 7% beat vs consensus, with net interest income ahead by £2.2m (+2%). See page 2 for details.

CET1 capital has strengthened to 13.3%, up 2.3% over the past 12 months, primarily reflecting the Rochester Financing disposal. Customer deposits of £5.8bn exceed customer loans of £5.4bn leaving OSB well placed to benefit under the BoE’s new “Term Funding Scheme”, so the NIM outlook improves.

BE

Underlying PBT of £64.6m is c9% better than CSe and 7% better than
consensus (largely due to better revenues, and lower impairments). Interim
dividend of 2.9p is in-line with policy of 1/3rd of prior year’s total dividend (vs
consensus 3p), and CET1 ratio of 13.3% was higher than CSe 12.8% and
consensus 12.6%. Supportive comments, with application levels in core
businesses in 2H “significantly higher” than 1H run-rate; that said OSB is
tightening lending criteria in “more cyclical smaller businesses” and being more
cautious about assessing portfolio purchases. Pre-Brexit guidance for 16E kept,
except that the loan growth target is modestly softer (see details below). Overall,
this looks a supportive set of results; the moderated growth targets are
understandable in-light of post-referendum uncertainty. That said, we think it is
too early to extrapolate (as with other SMID banks) current trends, given we are
only 2 months past the event. We continue to prefer ALD and SHAW (both OP)
which have more diversified business models.

11:55 am
BE

■ P&L numbers were robust – 1H16 revenues were £96.5m (CSe £92.7m)
with NII of £99.1 m (CSe £96.4m) and NIM of 3.07% (CSe 3.07% and
consensus 3.11%). On capital, the CET1 ratio of 13.3% was higher than CSe
12.8%, and consensus 12.6%.
■ Some moderation of growth targets – 20%+ target for 16E now excludes
the impact of Rochester disposal of £227m (previously had aimed to replace
this with organic growth); this implies YE16E net loans of c£5.9bn which is
in-line to modestly ahead of CSe. OSB targets “double digit” organic loan
growth for 17E, with potential upside from acquisitions – this compares with
CSe 9% (which is more conservative than company’s pre-Brexit ambition of
closer to 20%).

Should note also that RBC upgrades.

BE

We upgrade OneSavings Bank to Outperform from Sector Perform for the
following reasons:
The implied all-in return is now 26% (22% upside potential to our price
target plus a 4% dividend yield), making it one of the highest in our
coverage universe of 22 companies.
The increases to our forecasts are sizable; we increase our underlying
diluted EPS forecasts by 9% in 2016, 6% in 2017 and 3% in 2018; book
value per share estimates move 2% to 3% higher in each year as well.

11:57 am
BE

The increases to our forecasts are the result of both H1/16 results
that exceeded expectations and management’s guidance that is more
optimistic than we envisioned it would be. Management’s guidance is
supported by (1) application levels in OSB’s core businesses so far in H2/16
that are significantly higher than the first half run rate; (2) re-mortgaging
activity that continues to be buoyant and represents ~60% of Buy-to-Let
new origination; (3) net loan book guidance of above 16% for all of 2016;
(4) a stable net interest margin in 2016 (previously it was thought to be
declining), and (5) impairments that remain well-contained.
Further, even though we increase our forecasts in an uncertain economic
environment, we believe that absent a material house price correction
or a severe and/or sustained recession, and given the upside optionality
provided by OSB’s strong balance sheet, our revised, higher forecasts
present an achievable (and possibly conservative) picture of the
company’s growth trajectory. This is because our forecasts continue to
assume a moderation in the net interest margin, an increase in the costincome ratio, a near doubling of the impairment ratio, slowing loan book
growth, and a material decline in the return on equity (the latter of which
could be rectified by an increased payout ratio).
Lastly, OSB has “only” increased by 12% so far in Q3/16 (peer
average: +18%), and is the second worst performing company in
the peer group after Shawbrook, which has well-documented control
issues and management turnover. Thus, in our opinion the relative
underperformance presents an attractive entry point to a best-in-class
performing company, as OSB’s return on equity remains peer group
leading.
